description:
This course offers a comprehensive study of significant changes and continuities in the history of medicine from 1650-1850, alongside works of literature that exemplify the shifting notions of the doctor and sickness in the Western medical tradition. 

See the English Department's website at www.english.upenn.edu for a description of the current offerings.
name: MEDICINE & LITERATURE: Medicine in Literature and Film:  1850-Present

section.name: MEDICINE & LITERATURE: Medicine in Literature and Film:  1850-Present

values.comments:
This course is an intensive survey of fiction and poetry in the United States since World War II. Readings seek to explore developments in later twentieth-century culture, from cold war conflicts and the new velocities of mass media to the dizzying postmodern experiments in form. The authors read for this course vary from term to term.
Students were impressed with the quality of this course, describing it as “one of the most interesting and diverse classes” at Penn and not very difficult. The assigned courses were very valuable and students reported learning a lot from the material. However, students thought that the course was not well paced since “the syllabus is very top heavy and could be more evenly distributed”.
Professor Wahlert was well rated by his students for they believed him to be “incredibly enthusiastic and his energy is infectious in the classroom”. He greatly stimulated their interest during class discussions and “chose a diverse range of interesting primary and secondary sources”. Professor Wahlert was very accessible and students considered it a “real privilege to be one of his students”.
The course load was described as heavy, for there were many assigned readings and students were required to watch films outside of class. However, this was not a deterrent and the course still came highly recommended for both majors and non-majors.
